slides.title: Payments can be automatic or “responsive”
slides.originalNotes:
Payments can be automatic or "responsive"
In BillingCenter, a payment instrument specifies how a policyholder intends to submit payments to BillingCenter- The payment instrument represents the payment method such as a credit card or bank details.

Each insured account has one or more associated payment instruments with one payment instrument set as the default. Settings on the invoice stream allow you to override the payment instrument for policies with invoices in that invoice stream.

When the Payment Instrument field is set to a specific payment instrument, such as an ACHE-FT (Automated Clearing House/Electronic Funds Transfer) account or credit card, the insurer bills an automatic payment instrument, and the insured does not need to provide a response.
A payment instrument of Responsive means that the insurer bills the account directly and the insured must respond manually by sending a payment to the insurer.

Typically, sensitive financial information is stored in a secure external system. In this case, the payment instrument in BillingCenter contains a token, which is the identifier of credit card or other payment instrument in the external system.

All forms of electronic payment require some level of integration work to implement.

slides.title: Automatic payment overview (3 of 4)
slides.originalNotes:
Automatic payment overview (3 of 4)
3. What happens next depends on the insurer and the financial institution.

The financial institution can send the money to the insurer. Initially, the money is placed in an unapplied fund, from which a batch process will distribute it This scenario is illustrated in this and the next slide.

Alternatively, an insurer may decide to make the distribution immediately and not wait for the new payment batch or other batch that distributes money. Some insurers use an "assumed payment" model where they post a payment to BillingCenter on the payment request draft date, assuming that the payment is made. Some time later, the insurer reconciles receipts from the financial institution— this means the payment request itself is used to directly generate a payment internally in BillingCenter.

slides.title: All payments pass through an unapplied fund
slides.originalNotes:
All payments pass through an unapplied fund
All payments received by BillingCenter pass through an unapplied fund (T-account) before being allocated. A setting on the account determines whether the account uses a single unapplied fund for all of its policies or a separate unapplied fund for each policy. The invoice stream (not shown in the diagram) containing the invoices is associated with the applicable unapplied fund.

In the slide, the Cash Separation has been disabled on the account, which means that the account has a single unapplied fund. BillingCenter uses any positive balance in the unapplied fund to pay eligible invoice items for which the account is the payer (these can include policies owned and paid by this account, account-level charges, and invoice items owned by other accounts or producers if they are assigned to this account for payment).

slides.title: All payments pass through an unapplied fund
slides.originalNotes:
All payments pass through an unapplied fund
A single account can own a separate unapplied fund for each policy that the account pays. With cash separation in place, BillingCenter can automatically target a payment toward those eligible invoice items belonging to a policy that is associated with a specific designated unapplied T- account. BillingCenter will also take funds for any disbursement out of the relevant unapplied account.

Basically, cash separation means that payments are managed at the policy level. The focus of this course is cash separation.

A batch process using a payment allocation plan cannot cross unapplied boundaries when distributing money from unapplied. In other words, if cash separation is in place, a batch process cannot use money in one unapplied fund to allocate money to a policy that has a different unapplied fund, regardless of the payment allocation plan settings.

Note: An account always has an unapplied fund ("Default Unapplied") to handle money for account-level charges such as certain fees.

slides.title: Multiple Payment Entry wizard
slides.originalNotes:
Multiple Payment Entry wizard
You can enter several payments into BillingCenter from a single screen using the Multiple Payment Entry wizard, which is available from your desktop. Typically, you would use this method for payments that the customers have sent to the insurer through the mail or for payments that are listed on a bank statement where there is no integration with BillingCenter.
Step 1 of the wizard provides a full page of empty lines to allow for quick entry of several payments. You can add more lines by clicking Add. Search facilities are provided to help you locate the entity to which the money applies. After you enter a value for account, policy, invoice, or producer, the other three target fields are no longer editable. Step 2 of the wizard is simply a confirmation screen.

This screen supports direct bill, list bill, and agency bill, although the focus of this course is direct bill.

In the base application, Check and Cash are the only two payment instruments available on this screen. However, through configuration, you can configure the screen to handle other payment instruments that have payment methods such as credit card, automatic payments, bank transfers, and electronic transfers.

slides.originalNotes:
Entering a single payment
To enter a single payment using the Direct Bill Payment screen:

1. Go to the account that is making the payment.

2. Select the applicable unapplied fund. Ifthe account uses cash separation, you must select the designated unapplied account for the policy you are paying.

3. Enter the payment amount and payment instrument. The selected unapplied fund determines the invoice items that are displayed in the Preview Distribution area of the screen. Notice you can add a new payment instrument if required.

As soon as you navigate out of the Amount field after entering an amount, you can see the default allocation proposed byBillingCenter. The default allocation is controlled by the payment allocation plan associated with the account.

Click Execute to save your payment and allocation.

When an insured sends an advanced payment before an invoice is billed or if there is a question about a payment, you can click Execute Without Distribution to simply save the payment to the applicable unapplied fund.
